channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Student Leaders Charged Over Hong Kong Protest
item.description: Two student leaders of Hong Kong’s pro-democracy movement were charged with obstructing the police during a protest last year of a Chinese policy “white paper” asserting Beijing’s complete authority over Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Nathan Law and Joshua Wong speaking with demonstrators on Tuesday before reporting to the Western Police Station in Hong Kong, where they were charged with obstructing the police during a protest last year.

item.title: Text and Video: Obama’s Address on the Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: The full transcript, as provided by the White House, of President Obama’s remarks Tuesday morning on the nuclear deal with Iran.

item.title: Protesters Seek Return of Body of Tibetan Monk Who Died in Jail
item.description: The police fired shots into the air, used tear gas and beat demonstrators to disperse the crowds, an advocacy group said.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Congress to Start Review of Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Lawmakers have 60 days to scrutinize the accord and then to vote to accept or reject it — or to do nothing.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WEISMAN and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama said he would veto any legislation that would block the nuclear agreement with Iran.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Cinema on the Edge’ to Take Chinese Movies to New York
item.description: After the authorities effectively shut down the Beijing Independent Film Festival last year, a team decided to take a selection of Chinese movies to New York. The films will be screened from Aug. 7 to Sept. 13, featuring works by Ai Weiwei, Hu Jie, Li Luo, Zou Xueping and Yang Mingming.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Courtesy of the Beijing Independent Film Festival
item.media:description: Ai Weiwei’s “Ping’an Xueqing” (2011), a documentary examining the death of an activist who stood up for his fellow villagers in a land dispute with local officials, will be shown in New York at “Cinema on the Edge: The Best of the Beijing Independent Film Festival 2012-2014.”

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tsinghua Business Graduates Scrap Market-Oriented Slogan
item.description: The School of Economics and Management changed its graduation slogan from “Revive A shares! Benefit the people!” after an uproar online.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA LI
item.media:description: Graduates of Tsinghua University’s School of Economics and Management taking a group photo on Sunday.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Deal Is Reached With World Powers
item.description: The agreement will lift international oil and financial sanctions, in return for limits on Iran’s nuclear production capability and fuel stockpile over the next 15 years.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Delegates from Iran and a group of six nations led by the United States in Vienna on Tuesday after agreeing to an accord to significantly limit Tehran’s nuclear ability.

item.title: Indian Stampede Kills at Least 27 at Religious Festival
item.description: More than 30 people were hurt in the crush near the Godavari River in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh, according to health officials.
item.dc:creator: MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Indian devotees after a deadly stampede at the Maha Pushkaralu religious festival in Godavari, India, on Tuesday.

item.title: News Analysis: Bet for Obama on Iran Nuclear Deal May Take Years to Pay Off
item.description: The president will be long out of office before any reasonable assessment of his effort can be made, but the best guess is that the judgment will be mixed.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Obama is essentially betting that once sanctions have been lifted, Iran’s leaders will have no choice but to use much of the new money to better the lives of their citizens.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Better Restitution for Darfur
item.description: The billions seized from BNP Paribas’s money-laundering scheme for President Bashir should go to those who’ve suffered in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: ERIC REEVES

item.title: Chinese Police Say 3 Who Were Killed by Officers Were ‘Xinjiang Terrorists’
item.description: The men attacked officers trying to enter an apartment in the northeastern city of Shenyang, the authorities said, but Uighur advocates questioned the account.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Netanyahu Denounces Iran Nuclear Deal as a ‘Historic Mistake’
item.description: For the prime minister of Israel, the accord is the bitter culmination of a long struggle that has severely strained the country’s relations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Tuesday that the accord with Iran would allow Tehran to continue "its expansion and aggression throughout the Middle East and across the globe."

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: People’s Daily Details Allegations Against Lawyers Detained in China
item.description: China’s Communist Party newspaper publicized the allegations against five detained human rights lawyers, accusing them of running a “criminal syndicate” to put pressure on courts.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Hong Kong on Sunday protesting the recent detentions of human rights lawyers in China. Albert Ho, center, of the Democratic Party wore mock handcuffs.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Eurozone's Fault Lines
item.description: Without crucial reforms, the currency union is likely to remain in a political no man's land, whatever happens to Greece.
item.dc:creator: SIMON TILFORD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Our Drone War Burnout
item.description: Remote-control warfare is taking a toll at home with mounting levels of stress.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: PRATAP CHATTERJEE

item.title: Mexico Prison Break by ‘El Chapo’ Is a Blow to President Peña Nieto
item.description: The breakout of the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera shattered President Enrique Peña Nieto’s pledge to break with the corruption and incompetence of the past, and led Mexicans to question his government’s effectiveness.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN, RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: A federal police officer stood guard on Monday at a half-built house near the Altiplano maximum security prison outside Mexico City from which Joaquín Guzmán Loera escaped Saturday.

item.title: Open Source: Sympathy for Greeks Inspires Outraged Commentary Tagged #ThisIsACoup
item.description: The strict terms of the debt deal imposed on Greece prompted a wave of criticism on social networks.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Ukraine Premier, in White House Visit, Hails Economic Progress
item.description: Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk said his coalition was committed to tackling corruption, increasing wages and voting for changes to offer more power to the separatist East.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Satoru Iwata, Nintendo Chief Executive, Dies at 55
item.description: Under Mr. Iwata’s watch, Nintendo surged ahead of rival game companies with the release of the Nintendo DS, a hand-held system, and the popular Wii home console.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Satoru Iwata with the Wii U in 2011. He was fluent in the language of gaming and had an ease with young developers.

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Houthis Attack Refinery, Causing Huge Blaze
item.description: Houthi forces fired mortar rounds Monday at an oil refinery in the southern Yemeni city of Aden, hitting three full storage tanks.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
